AI.method: The paper proposes a deep model that uses a mechanism called MorphOverriding to encode both internal structures and representations of words while inducing character-level structures based on morphological rules without annotated data.
AI.result: The proposed method outperforms traditional tokenization methods like BPE and WordPiece in both morphological segmentation tasks and language modeling tasks, demonstrating superiority in retaining morphemes.
AI.conclusion: This new approach to tokenization effectively enhances semantic information retention by keeping complete morphemes intact, thus improving language processing tasks.
key_contributions: Introduces MorphOverriding for maintaining morpheme integrity in tokenization
Demonstrates superior performance over BPE and WordPiece methods
Provides a self-supervised training approach for character-level structure induction

title: Operationalizing a Threat Model for Red-Teaming Large Language Models (LLMs)
summary:
Creating secure and resilient applications with large language models (LLM)
requires anticipating, adjusting to, and countering unforeseen threats.
Red-teaming has emerged as a critical technique for identifying vulnerabilities
in real-world LLM implementations. This paper presents a detailed threat model
and provides a systematization of knowledge (SoK) of red-teaming attacks on
LLMs. We develop a taxonomy of attacks based on the stages of the LLM
development and deployment process and extract various insights from previous
research. In addition, we compile methods for defense and practical red-teaming
strategies for practitioners. By delineating prominent attack motifs and
shedding light on various entry points, this paper provides a framework for
improving the security and robustness of LLM-based systems.

AI.tldr: This paper provides a framework for improving the security of LLMs through a detailed threat model and red-teaming strategies.
AI.motivation: The need for secure and resilient applications using large language models due to unforeseen threats.
AI.method: Development of a taxonomy of red-teaming attacks based on the LLM development and deployment processes and a synthesis of previous research insights.
AI.result: Identification of prominent attack motifs and various entry points, alongside practical red-teaming strategies to fortify LLM-based systems.
AI.conclusion: The paper offers strategies to improve security and robustness of LLM implementations against identified vulnerabilities.
key_contributions: Development of a comprehensive threat model for LLMs
Systematization of red-teaming attack strategies
Compilation of defense methods for practitioners

title: Derailer-Rerailer: Adaptive Verification for Efficient and Reliable Language Model Reasoning
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown impressive reasoning capabilities,
yet existing prompting methods face a critical trade-off: simple approaches
often struggle with complex tasks and reasoning stability, while more
sophisticated methods require multiple inferences and substantial computational
resources, limiting their practical deployment. To address this challenge, we
propose Derailer-Rerailer, a novel framework that adaptively balances reasoning
accuracy and computational efficiency. At its core, our framework employs a
lightweight Derailer mechanism to assess reasoning stability and selectively
triggers an advanced Rerailer verification process only when necessary, thereby
optimizing computational resource usage. Extensive evaluation across both open
and closed-source models on more than 20 categories of mathematical, symbolic,
and commonsense reasoning tasks demonstrates our framework's effectiveness:
Derailer-Rerailer achieves significant accuracy improvements (8-11\% across
various reasoning tasks) while maintaining 2-3 times better efficiency than
existing verification methods, with particularly strong performance in
mathematical and symbolic reasoning, offering a practical solution for
enhancing LLM reasoning reliability while significantly reducing computational
overhead.

AI.tldr: Derailer-Rerailer is a framework that optimizes reasoning accuracy and computational efficiency in LLMs by using a lightweight assessment mechanism.
AI.motivation: To balance the trade-off between reasoning stability and computational efficiency in large language models (LLMs), especially for complex tasks.
AI.method: The framework employs a Derailer mechanism to assess reasoning stability and triggers an advanced Rerailer verification process only when needed, optimizing resource use.
AI.result: Achieves 8-11% improvement in accuracy across various reasoning tasks while being 2-3 times more efficient than existing verification methods.
AI.conclusion: Derailer-Rerailer provides a practical solution to enhance LLM reasoning reliability and reduce computational overhead.
key_contributions: Introduces Derailer-Rerailer framework for LLMs
Significant accuracy improvements on reasoning tasks
Enhanced efficiency compared to existing methods

title: Investigating Context-Faithfulness in Large Language Models: The Roles of Memory Strength and Evidence Style
comment: This work is published at ACL 2025
summary:
Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) improves Large Language Models (LLMs) by
incorporating external information into the response generation process.
However, how context-faithful LLMs are and what factors influence LLMs' context
faithfulness remain largely unexplored. In this study, we investigate the
impact of memory strength and evidence presentation on LLMs' receptiveness to
external evidence. We quantify the memory strength of LLMs by measuring the
divergence in LLMs' responses to different paraphrases of the same question,
which is not considered by previous works. We also generate evidence in various
styles to examine LLMs' behavior. Our results show that for questions with high
memory strength, LLMs are more likely to rely on internal memory. Furthermore,
presenting paraphrased evidence significantly increases LLMs' receptiveness
compared to simple repetition or adding details. These findings provide key
insights for improving retrieval-augmented generation and context-aware LLMs.
Our code is available at https://github.com/liyp0095/ContextFaithful.

AI.tldr: This paper explores how memory strength and evidence presentation affect the context faithfulness of Large Language Models (LLMs) in a retrieval-augmented generation setting.
AI.motivation: To understand and improve the context faithfulness of LLMs when using external information for response generation.
AI.method: The study measures memory strength by quantifying the divergence in LLMs' responses to different paraphrases of the same question and examines LLM behavior with evidence presented in various styles.
AI.result: For high memory strength questions, LLMs tend to rely more on internal memory. Additionally, paraphrased evidence enhances receptiveness significantly compared to mere repetition or detailed additions.
AI.conclusion: The findings highlight crucial factors influencing LLMs' context faithfulness and suggest improvements for retrieval-augmented generation methods.
key_contributions: Introduces a new measure of memory strength in LLMs based on response divergence to paraphrased questions.
Demonstrates the impact of paraphrased evidence presentation on LLM receptiveness.
Provides insights for enhancing context-aware functionalities in LLMs.
AI.limitations: The study primarily focuses on memory strength and does not explore other potential factors affecting LLMs' context faithfulness comprehensively.

title: TART: An Open-Source Tool-Augmented Framework for Explainable Table-based Reasoning
summary:
Current Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit limited ability to understand
table structures and to apply precise numerical reasoning, which is crucial for
tasks such as table question answering (TQA) and table-based fact verification
(TFV). To address these challenges, we introduce our Tool-Augmented Reasoning
framework for Tables (TART), which integrates LLMs with specialized tools. TART
contains three key components: a table formatter to ensure accurate data
representation, a tool maker to develop specific computational tools, and an
explanation generator to maintain explainability. We also present the TOOLTAB
dataset, a new benchmark designed specifically for training LLMs in table-tool
integration. Our experiments indicate that TART achieves substantial
improvements over existing methods (e.g., Chain-of-Thought) by improving both
the precision of data processing and the clarity of the reasoning process.
Notably, TART paired with CodeLlama achieves 90.0% of the accuracy of the
closed-sourced LLM GPT-3.5-turbo, highlighting its robustness in diverse
real-world scenarios. All the code and data are available at
https://github.com/XinyuanLu00/TART.

AI.tldr: Introducing Tool-Augmented Reasoning framework for Tables (TART), which enhances LLMs in understanding and processing table data for tasks like TQA and TFV.
AI.motivation: Current LLMs struggle with numerical reasoning and table data interpretation, impacting applications like table question answering and verification.
AI.method: TART integrates LLMs with a table formatter, a tool maker for computational tools, and an explanation generator for explainability.
AI.result: TART shows substantial performance improvements over existing methods, achieving accuracy close to GPT-3.5-turbo when paired with CodeLlama.
AI.conclusion: TART offers a more precise and clearer reasoning approach for table-related tasks, supported by the TOOLTAB dataset for model training.
key_contributions: Introduction of the TART framework for enhanced table reasoning
Creation of the TOOLTAB dataset for LLM training
Integration of specialized tools with LLMs for improved performance

title: Emoji Attack: Enhancing Jailbreak Attacks Against Judge LLM Detection
summary:
Jailbreaking techniques trick Large Language Models (LLMs) into producing
restricted output, posing a potential threat. One line of defense is to use
another LLM as a Judge to evaluate the harmfulness of generated text. However,
we reveal that these Judge LLMs are vulnerable to token segmentation bias, an
issue that arises when delimiters alter the tokenization process, splitting
words into smaller sub-tokens. This alters the embeddings of the entire
sequence, reducing detection accuracy and allowing harmful content to be
misclassified as safe. In this paper, we introduce Emoji Attack, a novel
strategy that amplifies existing jailbreak prompts by exploiting token
segmentation bias. Our method leverages in-context learning to systematically
insert emojis into text before it is evaluated by a Judge LLM, inducing
embedding distortions that significantly lower the likelihood of detecting
unsafe content. Unlike traditional delimiters, emojis also introduce semantic
ambiguity, making them particularly effective in this attack. Through
experiments on state-of-the-art Judge LLMs, we demonstrate that Emoji Attack
substantially reduces the unsafe prediction rate, bypassing existing
safeguards.

AI.tldr: Introducing Emoji Attack, a method exploiting token segmentation bias in LLMs to reduce harmful content detection accuracy by leveraging emojis.
AI.motivation: Jailbreaking techniques pose threats to LLMs by enabling harmful outputs, necessitating effective defenses.
AI.method: The paper explores the use of emojis as a novel way to exploit token segmentation bias by modifying text input before evaluation by Judge LLMs.
AI.result: Experiments show that Emoji Attack significantly reduces the rate of harmful content being detected by Judge LLMs.
AI.conclusion: Emoji Attack effectively bypasses safeguards of LLMs by introducing semantic ambiguity through emojis, lowering unsafe prediction rates.
key_contributions: Introduction of Emoji Attack for LLMs
Demonstration of token segmentation bias impact on detection accuracy
Empirical results showing reduced unsafe prediction rates in Judge LLMs

title: Inter-linguistic Phonetic Composition (IPC): A Theoretical and Computational Approach to Enhance Second Language Pronunciation
summary:
Learners of a second language (L2) often unconsciously substitute unfamiliar
L2 phonemes with similar phonemes from their native language (L1), even though
native speakers of the L2 perceive these sounds as distinct and
non-interchangeable. This phonemic substitution leads to deviations from the
standard phonological patterns of the L2, creating challenges for learners in
acquiring accurate L2 pronunciation. To address this, we propose
Inter-linguistic Phonetic Composition (IPC), a novel computational method
designed to minimize incorrect phonological transfer by reconstructing L2
phonemes as composite sounds derived from multiple L1 phonemes. Tests with two
automatic speech recognition models demonstrated that when L2 speakers produced
IPC-generated composite sounds, the recognition rate of target L2 phonemes
improved by 20% compared to when their pronunciation was influenced by original
phonological transfer patterns. The improvement was observed within a
relatively shorter time frame, demonstrating rapid acquisition of the composite
sound.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Inter-linguistic Phonetic Composition (IPC), a method to improve second language pronunciation by reconstructing L2 phonemes using L1 phonemes, resulting in a 20% improvement in speech recognition accuracy.
AI.motivation: Learners often struggle with L2 pronunciation due to the influence of their native language, leading to incorrect phonemic transfer that affects speech recognition.
AI.method: A novel computational method called Inter-linguistic Phonetic Composition (IPC) is proposed, which reconstructs L2 phonemes from multiple L1 phonemes to minimize incorrect phonological transfer.
AI.result: Tests showed a 20% improvement in the recognition rate of target L2 phonemes when L2 speakers used IPC-generated composite sounds compared to original pronunciation patterns.
AI.conclusion: The IPC method significantly enhances the accuracy of L2 pronunciation and shows rapid acquisition of the composite sounds generated.
key_contributions: Introduction of Inter-linguistic Phonetic Composition (IPC) method
Demonstrated improvement in automatic speech recognition for L2 phonemes
Rapid acquisition of composite phonetic sounds in learners

title: Understanding Chain-of-Thought in LLMs through Information Theory
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown impressive performance in complex
reasoning tasks through the use of Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning, allowing
models to break down problems into manageable sub-tasks. However, existing CoT
evaluation techniques either require annotated CoT data or fall short in
accurately assessing intermediate reasoning steps, leading to high rates of
false positives. In this paper, we formalize CoT reasoning in LLMs through an
information-theoretic lens. Specifically, our framework quantifies the
`information-gain' at each reasoning step, enabling the identification of
failure modes in LLMs without the need for expensive annotated datasets. We
demonstrate the efficacy of our approach through extensive experiments on toy
arithmetic, GSM8K and PRM800k datasets, where it significantly outperforms
existing outcome-based methods by providing more accurate insights into model
performance on individual subtasks.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes an information-theoretic framework for evaluating Chain-of-Thought reasoning in Large Language Models, enabling the identification of failure modes without requiring annotated datasets.
AI.motivation: Existing methods for evaluating CoT reasoning are either dependent on annotated data or ineffective in assessing intermediate reasoning, which can yield false positives.
AI.method: The proposed framework quantifies the 'information-gain' at each reasoning step, facilitating a more robust evaluation of the reasoning process in LLMs.
AI.result: The method significantly outperforms traditional outcome-based evaluation techniques, providing clearer insights into model performance on subtasks across various datasets.
AI.conclusion: The study validates that the information-theoretic approach effectively enhances the evaluation of LLMs' reasoning capabilities without relying on costly annotations.
key_contributions: Introduces an information-theoretic framework for CoT evaluation.
Quantifies information gain at each reasoning step.
Demonstrates improved evaluation accuracy over existing methods.
AI.limitations: The approach may still be limited by the inherent complexities of reasoning tasks and does not address all potential evaluation metrics.

title: Long-Form Speech Generation with Spoken Language Models
summary:
We consider the generative modeling of speech over multiple minutes, a
requirement for long-form multimedia generation and audio-native voice
assistants. However, textless spoken language models struggle to generate
plausible speech past tens of seconds, due to high temporal resolution of
speech tokens causing loss of coherence, architectural issues with
long-sequence training or extrapolation, and memory costs at inference time.
From these considerations we derive SpeechSSM, the first speech language model
family to learn from and sample long-form spoken audio (e.g., 16 minutes of
read or extemporaneous speech) in a single decoding session without text
intermediates. SpeechSSMs leverage recent advances in linear-time sequence
modeling to greatly surpass current Transformer spoken LMs in coherence and
efficiency on multi-minute generations while still matching them at the
utterance level. As we found current spoken language evaluations uninformative,
especially in this new long-form setting, we also introduce: LibriSpeech-Long,
a benchmark for long-form speech evaluation; new embedding-based and LLM-judged
metrics; and quality measurements over length and time. Speech samples, the
LibriSpeech-Long dataset, and any future code or model releases can be found at
https://google.github.io/tacotron/publications/speechssm/.

AI.tldr: SpeechSSM is a novel generative model for long-form speech that significantly improves coherence and efficiency over previous models by generating speech without text intermediates.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of existing textless spoken language models in generating coherent long-form speech beyond short durations.
AI.method: SpeechSSMs utilize linear-time sequence modeling to learn from and generate long-form spoken audio in a single decoding session, while introducing LibriSpeech-Long for evaluation.
AI.result: SpeechSSMs outperform current Transformer models in generating multi-minute speech while matching them at the utterance level, demonstrating significant improvements in coherence and efficiency.
AI.conclusion: The introduction of SpeechSSM and the LibriSpeech-Long benchmark represents a substantial advancement in the field of generative spoken language modeling, particularly for long-form audio generation.
key_contributions: Introduction of SpeechSSM for long-form speech generation without text intermediates
Development of the LibriSpeech-Long benchmark for evaluating long-form speech
Proposal of new metrics for quality measurement in long-form speech generation

title: Decoding AI Judgment: How LLMs Assess News Credibility and Bias
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly embedded in workflows that
involve evaluative processes. This raises the need to examine how such
evaluations are built, what assumptions they rely on, and how their strategies
diverge from those of humans. We benchmark six LLMs against expert
ratings--NewsGuard and Media Bias/Fact Check (MBFC)--and against human
judgments collected through a controlled experiment. To enable direct
comparison, we implement a structured agentic framework in which both models
and non-expert participants follow the same evaluation procedure: selecting
criteria, retrieving content, and producing justifications. Despite output
alignment, LLMs rely on different mechanisms: lexical associations and
statistical priors replace contextual reasoning. This reliance produces
systematic effects: political asymmetries, opaque justifications, and a
tendency to confuse linguistic form with epistemic validity. Delegating
judgment to such systems does not merely automate evaluation--it redefines it,
shifting from normative reasoning to pattern-based approximation.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates how Large Language Models (LLMs) perform evaluative processes compared to human judgments and expert ratings, revealing significant differences in mechanisms and implications for judgment automation.
AI.motivation: The need to understand how LLMs handle evaluations, the assumptions behind these evaluations, and their divergence from human strategies is crucial as LLMs are increasingly used in evaluative contexts.
AI.method: Benchmarking six LLMs against expert ratings and human judgments through a structured framework where LLMs and human participants followed the same evaluation procedure: selecting criteria, retrieving content, and producing justifications.
AI.result: LLMs showed output alignment with human evaluations but relied on lexical associations and statistical priors instead of contextual reasoning, leading to political asymmetries and opaque justifications.
AI.conclusion: Automating evaluation with LLMs changes the nature of evaluation itself, moving from normative reasoning to a reliance on pattern-based approximation.
key_contributions: A structured agentic framework for LLMs and human evaluations
Insights into the mechanisms used by LLMs versus humans
Identification of systematic effects due to LLM evaluation strategies
AI.limitations: The study's sample size and selection of LLMs may limit the generalizability of findings.

title: Good/Evil Reputation Judgment of Celebrities by LLMs via Retrieval Augmented Generation
summary:
The purpose of this paper is to examine whether large language models (LLMs)
can understand what is good and evil with respect to judging good/evil
reputation of celebrities. Specifically, we first apply a large language model
(namely, ChatGPT) to the task of collecting sentences that mention the target
celebrity from articles about celebrities on Web pages. Next, the collected
sentences are categorized based on their contents by ChatGPT, where ChatGPT
assigns a category name to each of those categories. Those assigned category
names are referred to as "aspects" of each celebrity. Then, by applying the
framework of retrieval augmented generation (RAG), we show that the large
language model is quite effective in the task of judging good/evil reputation
of aspects and descriptions of each celebrity. Finally, also in terms of
proving the advantages of the proposed method over existing services
incorporating RAG functions, we show that the proposed method of judging
good/evil of aspects/descriptions of each celebrity significantly outperform an
existing service incorporating RAG functions.

AI.tldr: Examines LLMs' ability to judge celebrity reputations as good or evil using retrieval augmented generation (RAG) methodology.
AI.motivation: To investigate if large language models can effectively assess the good/evil reputation of celebrities based on online content.
AI.method: Utilized ChatGPT to collect and categorize sentences related to celebrity reputation from web articles, then applied RAG to evaluate these reputations.
AI.result: Showed that the method significantly outperforms existing services using RAG for judging celebrity reputations.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method demonstrates better effectiveness in analyzing celebrity reputations compared to current solutions.
key_contributions: Introduced a new approach for assessing celebrity reputations using LLMs and RAG.
Validated the effectiveness of LLMs in categorizing and judging reputations based on online articles.
Established a comparative analysis against existing RAG services.
